;美国有责任“按惯例行事”，受美国制裁的香港特首李家超表示，邀请成员参加今年在旧金山举行的 Apec 峰会。

;

;周二，当被问及亚洲问题时，香港行政长官把球交给了组织者。 - 11 月中旬的太平洋经济合作组织会议，加入香港作为成员，一直是年度高级别贸易会议的一部分。

;

;“APEC 是一个国际组织。它不属于任何国家或经济体。根据 Apec 规则和公约，组织者有责任邀请成员参加，”李说。

;

;“组织者有责任按照这些公约行事。”

;< p>;几位政府消息人士早些时候告诉邮报，虽然政府还没有关于 Apec 的实质性计划，但预计美国总统乔拜登可能会取消美国对李的制裁，因为华盛顿“对待香港官员的方式比那些人好得多”来自中国内地”。

;

;香港特首首度海外出访出席顶级论坛

;

;今年亚太经合组织经济领导人周将于11月在旧金山举行。李明博去年作为市领导首次出访，参加了泰国的分期会议。

;

;目前尚不清楚这位行政长官是否会获得美国当局的签证参加下一次峰会，他将在会上分享与拜登和其他国家元首同台。

;

;香港领导人的亚太经合组织之行“是重获外国信心的一大步”

;

;李是美国政府 2020 年制裁的 11 名官员之一表彰他们在执行北京实施的国家安全法方面发挥的作用。华盛顿声称该立法破坏了香港的自治权。

;

;香港领导人在 1 月份表示，他希望亲自出席峰会，因为这有利于向世界讲述香港的“真实而伟大的故事”。

; Tue, 30 May 2023 11:50:02 +0800 Venezuela’s Maduro visits Brazil in blow to US strategy of isolationhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/americas/article/3222259/venezuelas-maduro-visits-brazil-blow-us-strategy-isolation?utm_source=rss_feed

;委内瑞拉总统尼古拉斯·马杜罗呼吁建立一个“多极”世界，而不是一个由美国，他抵达巴西寻求在多年孤立之后重建他的国家的联盟。

;

;马杜罗在他七个月来的首次国际访问中于周一在巴西利亚会见了总统路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦。地区峰会。

;

;他的访问是左翼人士去年在巴西和哥伦比亚赢得选举后对委内瑞拉政府的态度正在缓和的最新证据。

;

;马杜罗的国际旅行最近受到限制多年来，美国一直公开支持推翻他的制裁。

;

;卢拉，这位 77 岁的巴西领导人，一再批评美国的政策，从委内瑞拉制裁到委内瑞拉武装力量乌克兰政府努力让维基解密创始人朱利安阿桑奇被引渡。

;

;“一个国家对其实施 900 项制裁是莫名其妙的，因为另一个国家不喜欢它，”卢拉说，对

;

;巴西的卢拉对未能在 G7 会议上与泽伦斯基会面感到“不安”

;

;在马杜罗于 2018 年连任后，美国总统唐纳德特朗普政府联合其盟友孤立委内瑞拉在一次被广泛认为是虚假的投票中。美国的制裁加深了其经济崩溃，导致数百万人逃离该国。

;

;虽然美国因担心 2022 年俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后出现能源短缺而略微减轻了对这个石油资源丰富的国家的压力，但许多国家其最严厉的处罚仍然存在：在指控马杜罗和其他高级官员参与 2020 年的贩毒阴谋后，政府目前悬赏 1500 万美元逮捕马杜罗。马杜罗否认这些指控。

;< p>;60 岁的马杜罗是已故乌戈·查韦斯 (Hugo Chavez) 亲手挑选的继任者，他在大规模抗议和政变企图中继续掌权。现在，随着左翼领导人在拉丁美洲大多数最大国家的执政，他的政府正在由其邻国恢复原状。

;

;周一，卢拉表示他支持委内瑞拉加入被称为“金砖四国”的新兴市场国家集团，并承诺促进该国的商业发展。

;

;巴西总统一再反驳对委内瑞拉政府的批评，委内瑞拉政府因其侵犯人权和经济处理不当而受到广泛谴责。

;

;“马杜罗没有进口美元，”他说。 “这是美国的错，它造成了极其夸张的封锁。”

;

;马杜罗同时欢呼两国关系进入“新时代”。

;

;“巴西和委内瑞拉必须团结一致，从现在开始，永远如此，”他说。

;

;这次访问招致了反对者的批评。

;

;巴西领导人结束对中国的访问时告诉美国“停止鼓励”战争

;

;“巴西重新欢迎南美独裁者获得国家荣誉，”反对派参议员塞尔吉奥·莫罗在 Twitter 上写道。

;

;在整个地区，甚至马杜罗的一些批评者也采取措施重新参与。上周，智利总统加布里埃尔·博里奇 (Gabriel Boric) 任命了一位新任驻委内瑞拉大使，该职位自 2018 年以来一直空缺。

;

;外交部长阿尔贝托·范克拉维伦 (Alberto van Klaveren) 周一表示，两国之间需要建立牢固的工作关系国家在共同感兴趣的领域，例如移民。

;

;2022 年底，哥伦比亚领导人古斯塔沃·佩特罗正式重新开放他的国家与委内瑞拉的边界。

;

; Tue, 30 May 2023 11:20:02 +0800 ‘Not giving up on a good teacher’: parents back educator fired for beating students with a stick over rude gestureshttps://www.scmp.com/news/people-culture/trending-china/article/3221785/not-giving-good-teacher-parents-back-educator-fired-beating-students-stick-over-rude-gestures?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.30 11:00;
;;

;中国南方一名小学教师因体罚超过10 名学生后来被数十名家长要求留下是大陆社交媒体上在线辩论的中心。

;

;广东省东莞市一所学校的小学二年级老师在对一名学生进行纪律处分后被解雇她说有一群学生在课堂上做了不恰当的手势。广东卫视报道称，该老师一边让学生长时间打武术蹲姿，一边用棍子打他们。

;

;报道没有透露老师的身份，也没有报道是否

;

;当学校以解雇老师作为回应时，她班上 47 名学生中有 44 名的家长呼吁学校让老师留下来，称他们对老师的整体表现感到满意

;

;一位女儿是受罚学生之一的女士说，她并没有因为自己的行为而责怪老师，并说她的行为是“冲动的”。

;

;“我的孩子与这位女士说，她的名字没有出现在报告中。

;

;“我很高兴再给这位老师一次改正错误的机会。”

;

;另一位不愿透露姓名的父亲说老师应该留下来。

;

;“我对我的孩子也很严格。我曾经告诉老师，因为我的孩子在她班上，我完全信任她，”父亲说。

;

;老师说她对自己的行为感到后悔，并公开向学生道歉。

;

;“我没有控制住自己的脾气。我做了一些我不应该做的事。在使用体罚之前，我没有仔细考虑，最终没有对学生使用适当的管教方法。对不起！”

;

;该校高层秦千峰表示，这位老师是一位称职的教职工，其教学质量得到了广大家长的认可。< /p>;

;“她教得好，责任心强。她负责的班级经常获得荣誉旗，”秦说。 “我们也希望她能在这里继续发挥她的作用。”

;

;这起案件在大陆社交媒体上引起了公众关注，大多数人表示支持体罚，称他们“没有放弃好老师”

;

;一人说：“以后再聪明的老师也不会管教学生了。孩子学得好不好，不关老师的事。老师只会提醒家长。仅此而已。”

;

;另一个人呼吁恢复体罚形式的套箍，套箍是一种长尺，传统上用于通过拍打孩子的手来惩罚顽皮的孩子：“套箍应该归还给老师。”

;

;然而，并非所有在线评论者都支持使用体罚。

;

;“我不接受她用棍子打学生。武术下蹲让学生做可以，但打学生实在不妥。”

;

;在中国，老师不做就用戒尺打学生手掌曾经是家常便饭表现良好。然而，中国的《教师法》和《未成年人保护法》禁止教师使用体罚。

;

;上个月，山东省东部的一名中学教师因监控录像显示他用拳头猛烈踢打学生而被停职糟糕的测试结果在网上发布，引起了公众的强烈反对。

; Tue, 30 May 2023 11:20:02 +0800 China population: re-employment of elderly an ‘urgent, realistic problem to be solved’https://www.scmp.com/economy/economic-indicators/article/3222204/china-population-re-employment-elderly-urgent-realistic-problem-be-solved?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.30 11:00;
;;

;中国官方媒体提高了鼓励更多退休人员再就业的基调随着该国与人口减少和老龄化作斗争，通过呼吁投资于职业培训和改善老年人就业法规来加入劳动力队伍。

;

;国营经济日报周一呼吁当局鼓励更多的人60岁以上老人重新就业，“老年人再就业已成为亟待解决的现实问题”。

;

;这呼应了人民日报上周的观点，称中国137万健康和相对年轻的老年人是“有待开发的新红利”。

;

;“随着人口老龄化，许多行业需要老年人继续发挥作用，他们也有继续工作的愿望……通过倡导积极老龄化观念，提高全社会对人口老龄化的认识，可以为老年人再就业营造积极氛围，”中国劳动和社会保障研究院研究员赵必谦告诉经济每日。

;

;赵指出人口老龄化国家，如日本和法国，它们建立了老年人大学，为雇用 70 岁以上人员的公司提供奖励，并提供社区服务来帮助老年人找到工作.

;

;中国男性法定退休年龄为 60 岁，女性上班族为 55 岁，女性蓝领工人为 50 岁，而中国的平均预期寿命为 77.93 岁。

;

;远低于发达国家，北京考虑推迟退休年龄，但细节尚未敲定。

;

;2022年底，中国60岁以上人口刚刚超过2.8亿，占19.8%

;

;然而，中国只有 8.8% 的劳动力年龄在 60 岁以上。

;

;中国就业新模式研究中心主任张成刚首都经济贸易大学的王某对经济日报记者表示，现行的退休老人再就业制度并没有充分保障退休老人的权益。

;

;“用人单位聘用60岁以上的老人，只需支付报酬，不需要缴纳社会保障基金，”张说。

;

;“现行法律不保护再就业的老人。一旦发生劳资纠纷或工伤事故，超过法定退休年龄的他们可能不受劳动法保护。”

;

;人才红利能否在人口减少和老龄化的背景下保持中国竞争力？< /h3>;

;张呼吁政府实施反年龄歧视的政策，以保护老年工人的权利。

;

;企业也应该照顾年长工人的需求，他们更喜欢弹性工作时间并且不能从事体力消耗大或工伤风险高的工作。

;

;中国 16 至 59 岁的劳动年龄人口从 2012 年到 2019 年减少了超过 2600 万，给不断减少的劳动力带来压力，以支付越来越多的退休人员的养老金。

;

;到 2022 年底，这一数字为 8.7556 亿，占总人口的 62%，但这低于比去年同期高出62.5%。

;

;北京市人口协会副会长尹德廷也告诉经济日报，大多数老年人工作是为了贴补生活费、保持灵活就业或发展技能

;

;“然而，面对日益激烈的市场竞争和不断变化的职业要求，许多愿意参与劳动力的老年人往往面临进入门槛高、就业面窄等问题。 -寻求渠道，竞争力不足，与市场需求不匹配，”殷说。

;

;他们的工作往往仅限于餐饮、保洁、保安、护理等服务行业。”

;

;尹补充说，老年职业机构应优先培训利用技术弥合数字鸿沟，并提供更好的就业匹配服务。

; Tue, 30 May 2023 11:20:02 +0800 Japan comic ‘Tony’ Yasumura’s near-naked stage act takes Britain’s Got Talent by stormhttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/3222253/japan-comic-tony-yasumuras-near-naked-stage-act-takes-britains-got-talent-storm?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.30 10:31;
;;

;病毒式传播的 shtick 以足球运动员、辣妹、詹姆斯·邦德为特色，随便你怎么说，看起来是赤裸的，除了他们根本不是真正的赤裸。

;

;日本漫画 Tonikaku Akarui Yasumura 的解除武装的视觉噱头很简单而且相当愚蠢。但它关于所见所闻具有欺骗性的赤裸裸的信息却让很多人发笑。

;

;托尼最近出现在英国达人秀上吸引了 10 多人试镜节目的 YouTube 帐户上有 100 万次观看。

;

;“以一种庄严的尊严和完全没有根据的自信来做这件事，”他最近在东京谈到他的喜剧秘诀时说。 “这就结束了，因为你所做的事太荒唐了。”

;

;Yasumura 近十年来一直在日本各地的电视节目和喜剧院表演他的标志性表演。

;

;他只穿着粉红色花朵图案的泳衣站在观众面前，宣布他要描绘一个裸体的人。

;

;然后他抬起一条腿，双手合十坐着，或蹲下，有策略地小心翼翼地蹲下调整好自己的位置，这样他唯一的衣服就看不见了。

;

;“别担心，”他用友好、安心的语气说。

;

;日本威胁在朝鲜之后采取“破坏性措施”警告卫星发射

;

;“I'm wearing”，他补充说，但没有多说，因为在日语中，句子的宾语通常是不说出来的。

;

;在英国节目中，评委们为他说完，大声喊道：“裤子！”

;

;安村说他可以用这种方式描绘任何人，包括政治家、音乐明星或做日常事情（如喝茶）的普通人。

;

;“这很有趣。这绝对没有任何意义，”41 岁的安村说，他笑得很开心，但显然对自己的手艺非常认真。

;

;你必须始终保持微笑。永远，永远不要退缩。

;

;他承认他几乎不明白节目评委在说什么，内心也不确定该怎么做。但他没有跳过一个节拍。

;

;“老实说，你是我们今年最有趣的参赛者，说真的。真的，真的很有趣，而且很有创意，”该节目的制作人西蒙·考威尔滔滔不绝地说，他通常是最严厉的评委之一。

;

;“他带来了自信、喜剧，幸运的是他的裤子！ Tonikaku 通过他出色的试镜让我们从头到尾都兴奋不已，”该节目在一份声明中说。

;

;克服地缘政治分歧，日本歌手成为中国的新星

;

;幽默Yasumura 的表演植根于日本版的歌舞杂耍，其中包括由解说员扮演所有角色的传统讲故事，以及单口相声。

;

;Hadaka gei，字面意思是“裸体” acts”，构成日本喜剧的一种类型。

;

;这不同于表演，例如杂耍表演、演奏乐器或跳舞，无论它最终可能变得多么有趣，因为他Yasumura 说，它确实构成了日本喜剧艺术或 neta。

;

;Neta 也被用来描述美食烹饪的成分或新闻报道的独家新闻，换句话说，它是正在展开的事情的关键内核.

;

;当他在一本书的封面上看到一个女流行偶像时，他偶然想到了他的想法，是的，裸体姿势，只是她坐在一个让你想象她可能是裸体的位置，当你看到是她的腿、脸和手臂。

;

;“这和我的 neta 完全一样。我看到了，就知道：就是这样，”他说。从那以后他就没有停止过。

;

;他在英国达人秀上的成功在国内引起了共鸣。许多人在网上留下了振奋人心的评论，指出他让他们感到如此自豪，见证了跨越国界的喜剧。

;

;足球明星本田圭佑在 Twitter 上发布了一张他踢球的照片，旁边是一张安村踢球的照片裸体足球运动员的姿势。 “我穿着，”本田发推文说。

;

;知名作家松子德莱克斯在最近的电视节目中指出，安村并不害怕自嘲，而现代幽默往往倾向于

;

;安村虽然一副天真无邪的样子，但在他那赤裸的可爱中，也有一种力量。很明显，多年来，即使没有人笑，他也一遍又一遍地做他的裤子噱头。

;

;即使在今天，一些在线观察家已经抨击 Yasumura 是愚蠢的，如果不是冒犯的话。

;

;Yasumura 说他很幸运，因为他不需要做任何特别的事情来保持他的胖乎乎的身材。

;

;“所有正确的成分”：日本喜剧大师将江湖医生带入生活

;

;仍然，坚持一种自我表达方式需要奉献精神和勇气。毕竟，很明显他不害怕几乎赤身裸体地站在观众面前。

;

;他发誓他会一直做他的例行公事直到他死。

;

;如果他做到了节目的半决赛，Yasumura 不确定他到底会做什么，也许是 Elton John 或 Freddie Mercury 裸体。

;

;但别担心：他会穿裤子。

;随着气候变化、高通胀及其持续影响，孟加拉国必须关注减少收入不平等据一位联合国贫困问题专家称，大流行使数百万人陷入了“新穷人”的行列。

;

;孟加拉国的极端贫困人口从 2000 年的 34% 减少到 2016 年的 13%，根据世界银行的数据。

;

;但是，这一进展并未显示这个拥有近 1.7 亿人口的国家的贫困状况的全貌，生活成本的增加加剧了不平等，联合国特别报告员奥利维耶·德舒特 (Olivier De Schutter) 说极端贫困和人权。

;

;De Schutter 在《亚洲周刊》中说，孟加拉国出现了一种“新贫困人口”，其家庭徘徊在贫困线之上，储蓄不足，面临堕落的高风险

;

;“这是该国通货膨胀率非常高的结果……生活成本也上涨了 8-9%， “ 他说。 “这将对穷人造成不成比例的影响，削弱低收入并造成粮食不安全和债务。”

;

;孟加拉国 4 月份的通货膨胀率估计为 9.2%，其中食品通货膨胀率为 8.8% %，根据孟加拉国统计局的数据。此外，该国衡量收入不平等的基尼系数从 2010 年的 0.456 上升到 2016 年的 0.482。

;

;孟加拉国将于 2026 年摆脱联合国最不发达国家的地位，但这一里程碑可能证明De Schutter 在本月对这个南亚国家进行正式访问后表示，这是一把双刃剑。

;

;“原则上，这是一件好事，因为它表明孟加拉国取得了显着的经济进步，但它还将迫使它重新发明其发展模式，”他说。 “如果没有这种地位，孟加拉国将失去某些贸易优惠和进入欧盟、加拿大和美国主要市场的优惠准入，严重限制其出口能力。”

;

;拉纳广场十年后，孟加拉国联合国专家表示，工人们争取更好的工资和工作条件

;

;孟加拉国仍然危险地依赖其成衣业，该行业占其出口收入的 82%。

;

; De Schutter 说，该国需要推动国内经济“允许工资增长和加强社会保护以创造这种国内需求”。

;

;关于气候变化，De Schutter 预测未来几年会很艰难，并预测未来影响该国的干旱、飓风和洪水等极端天气事件将变得更加频繁和严重。

;

;“孟加拉国已经有许多人，特别是贫困人口，因近年来与气候有关的灾难，”德舒特说。根据联合国 12 月份的数据，超过 1000 万孟加拉国人被视为气候难民，到 2050 年，预计七分之一的人将因气候变化而流离失所。

;

;

;

; De Schutter 在这份内容广泛的报告中表示，孟加拉国的公民空间越来越受到限制，高层缺乏问责制将不利于消除贫困的长期进展。

;

;“我当时许多人权捍卫者、非政府组织、甚至学者和记者所面临的恐惧和恐吓气氛令他深感震惊，”他说。

;

;“政府无法在对减少如果没有问责制、没有透明度，如果你不能谴责腐败或资金管理不善，就会陷入贫困。”

;

;去年，示威者走上首都达卡街头，抗议停电和生活和燃料成本上涨。

;

;但自 2009 年以来领导该国的总理谢赫·哈西娜 (Sheikh Hasina) 统治期间，公众对涉嫌金融腐败和民主自由下降的不满情绪持续多年，也突显了抗议活动.

;

;联合国特别报告员发现，特别是《数字安全法》（2018 年）已被用作压制言论自由的工具，尤其是在线言论自由。

;

;观察员说，数以千计自该法颁布以来，他们都受到了指控，其中包括人权捍卫者、记者、学生和反对派政客。

;

;在某些情况下，据称被拘留者在拘留期间受到骚扰和酷刑。著名作家穆什塔克·艾哈迈德 (Mushtaq Ahmed) 于 2021 年 2 月去世，根据同一法律被拘留，这被抗议者称为“监禁谋杀”。

;

;

;

;联合国的任务还包括访问广阔的难民营家园近 100 万罗兴亚难民，一个无国籍的穆斯林少数民族，在他们的祖国缅甸受到迫害。

;

;他们无法在孟加拉国拥挤的难民营外自由生活和工作，并在恶劣的条件下苦苦挣扎。

;

;“我认为，在我担任极端贫困和人权问题特别报告员的这些年里，我几乎从未见过处于如此绝望境地的人，”德舒特在访问科克斯巴扎尔市的难民营时说.

;

;'我们自己土地上的客人'：难民营中的罗兴亚人不会返回缅甸

;

;“他们勉强生存。他们没有前途，他们不认为自己的处境会有所改善，”他说。

;

;“孟加拉国一直非常慷慨地在其领土上接纳了近 100 万难民，但这是基于以下预期：它将得到国际社会的支持。”

; Tue, 30 May 2023 09:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong’s vanishing books: as public libraries clear shelves of sensitive titles, can readers turn to shops or are they also becoming wary?https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3222034/hong-kongs-vanishing-books-public-libraries-clear-shelves-sensitive-titles-can-readers-turn-shops-or?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.30 09:00;
;;

;Hong Kong bookstores have become the centre of attention since the city's public libraries ramped up efforts to clear shelves of titles that posed potential national security risks.

;

;Gone from the shelves of these shops are books about Beijing's 1989 crackdown on student protesters at Tiananmen Square and titles by prominent Hong Kong pro-democracy figures, including the late Szeto Wah, while those about the 2019 social unrest have become harder to find.

;

;The libraries' action has spilled over to Hong Kong schools too, with some anxious educators pulling potentially sensitive books from their shelves. Some have removed George Orwell's classics, Animal Farm and 1984.

;

;Hong Kong library books must pass review before going back on shelves: minister

;

;Officials stressed they were not banning books, with culture minister Kevin Yeung Yun-hung saying the volumes would be back on public library shelves if it was found that their contents did not violate the law.

;

;Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu defended the libraries' actions and suggested there was nothing for anyone to get worked up about.

;

;“These books are accessible to people in private bookshops. If they want to buy them, they can still buy them,” he said in mid-May.

;

;But a Post check of 29 bookstores across the city found that many were not available, especially those published more than five years ago.

;

;Post interviews with booksellers and publishers showed that the libraries' action had a chilling effect, with local authors saying they might have to get their works published in Taiwan.

;

;Some book lovers said they were also racing against time to collect “challenged books” or send copies to university libraries in Taiwan and Britain to ensure that they would not disappear entirely.

;

;'Better to keep a low profile'

;

;Public libraries began removing books after Beijing imposed the national security law in 2020, banning acts of secession, subversion, terrorism, and collusion with foreign groups.

;

;But they stepped up such action recently, after audit officials demanded last month that they speed up examining materials for security risks.

;

;Hong Kong authorities have never revealed the list of challenged books, but scrutiny of the library catalogue showed that at least hundreds of titles have been pulled, the latest including non-political ones by pro-democracy figures and scholars.

;

;The Post visited or called 29 bookstores, including chains and independent ones, to check if some of the titles removed by the libraries were still on sale.

;

;The stores were asked if they had books about the Tiananmen Square crackdown, the 2019 anti-government protests in Hong Kong and those by scholars and opposition figures whose books had been removed from library shelves.

;

;Books about the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Square military crackdown, long considered a taboo subject in mainland China, had practically disappeared in Hong Kong. Only a new drama script about the event, May 35, by a Taiwan publisher was open for pre-orders at several independent bookstores.

;

;“We are actually not sure if new books can clear customs,” an employee at a bookstore in Sham Shui Po said. “The older books are all out of print.”

;

;A second-hand bookstore in Wan Chai had a book of poems by late Chinese literary critic Liu Xiaobo, a Tiananmen Square activist who went on to receive the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, but none of the other bookshops stocked his works.

;

;Books about the 2019 social unrest in Hong Kong were available at nearly a third of the bookstores surveyed.

;

;At a store in Sheung Wan, a few pictorial books by Japanese photographer Michiko Kiseki on the months of anti-government protests were stacked in a pile at a corner.

;

;“We won't display these last few copies in prominent spots. It'd be better to keep a low profile,” an employee said.

;

;The public libraries have removed the works of some Hong Kong pro-democracy figures, including all 35 books by the late Democratic Party whip Szeto Wah, former Civic Party member Margaret Ng Ngoi-yee's reviews of martial arts novels and former democrat Roy Kwong Chun-yu's romance novels.

;

;'Serving societal interest': Hong Kong leader defends removal of library books

;

;'Sorry, we don't have that book'

;

;Szeto's 2016 memoir, The Great River Flows East, was available at only one independent bookstore in Mong Kok, where an employee said there was only one copy left.

;

;Ng's three latest books, on the rule of law and a reflection on her 18 years in politics, were still on bookstore shelves, but her older titles were not available.

;

;Independent bookseller Jayson Yu, 34, said that since public libraries stepped up clearing their shelves, more customers had come to his Littlelittlebooks store in Yuen Long looking for challenged titles.

;

;“The government's action is like sounding a siren not to take the freedom to read for granted,” he said in his 200 sq ft shop stocked with about 1,000 new and second-hand titles, ranging from novels to comics and books on politics.

;

;He said his tiny bookshop struggled to survive, selling only about four books a day, and whenever titles sold out, he could get only a handful from publishers to replenish stocks.

;

;His shop is among about 100 independent bookstores in the city, dozens of which opened after the 2019 protests. Some were branded “yellow” shops for selling materials about the unrest and inviting pro-democracy authors to give talks.

;

;Beijing mouthpiece Ta Kung Pao earlier criticised former opposition district councillor Leticia Wong Man-huen for selling books about “black violence” and spreading anti-China ideology by holding events at her Hunter Bookstore in Sham Shui Po.

;

;Bestsellers at the shop, in business for a year, include American historian Timothy Snyder's Tyranny: Twenty Lessons from the Twentieth Century and books about the 2019 unrest.

;

;“It's too easy to remind me to be careful,” said Wong, 30. “Of course, the safest way to be a bookseller is to forgo selling Animal Farm, but I won't.”

;

;The Post found that many of the challenged books removed by the public libraries were not available at the city's largest bookstore chains too.

;

;These included more than 40 stores run by the Commercial Press, Chung Hwa Book Company and Joint Publishing, which are under Bauhinia Culture Holdings, a state-owned enterprise, through Sino United Publishing.

;

;A long-time employee of Joint Publishing told the Post that since the 2019 unrest, branch managers no longer had a say in choosing books to stock and promote. That was now determined by top management.

;

;New chapter for Hong Kong's independent booksellers or end of story?

;

;Publishers not keen to reprint challenged titles

;

;Hong Kong publishers have not been immune to the effect of the public libraries' recent actions.

;

;A veteran industry insider said some local publishers were steering clear of reprinting titles removed by the libraries.

;

;Szeto's memoir, for example, first published in 2011 by the Oxford University Press (China), had sold out at most bookstores and at the publisher's website.

;

;The insider said that after the early retirement of veteran managing editor Lam To-kwan, the company shifted its focus mainly to educational books.

;

;Asked if the memoir would be reprinted, a spokeswoman for the company said: “No such plans for now.” As such, the book would not be on display at in this year's book fair, she added.

;

;Hong Kong public libraries pull books related to Tiananmen Square crackdown

;

;She was referring to the annual book event organised by the Hong Kong Trade Development Council in July.

;

;Another book missing at most stores was People Will Not Forget, a recollection of the Tiananmen Square crackdown by 64 Hong Kong journalists, first published in 1989 and reprinted in 2010.

;

;It was published by the Hong Kong Journalists Association, which once put the full text on its website, but later closed the page.

;

;Referring to both books, the industry insider said: “It's understandable that they are not reprinting them. They don't want to do anything to instigate the government.”

;

;Hong Kong's libraries told to quickly root out books 'contrary' to national security

;

;Publish in Taiwan? That could be risky too

;

;Some of the bestselling Chinese-language titles on sale at independent bookstores but no longer available at public libraries were published in Taiwan.

;

;They include Memoirs of a Loser by Li Yi, an activist Hong Kong writer and columnist, who died last October, the Chinese version of Hong Kong Diaries by the last British governor, Chris Patten, and Resistant Community, by Chinese University political scientist Ma Ngok.

;

;Ma's book, first published in 2020, is in its eighth edition and regarded as one of the bestselling scholarly works about the 2019 protests.

;

;Ivan Choy Chi-keung, also an academic and author of about 20 books, said there could be different considerations when publishing in Taiwan.

;

;“A prerequisite is to satisfy Taiwanese readers' appetite. That means writers might have to adopt a different approach, or remove details which may be understood only by Hong Kong people,” he said.

;

;“Is this good for the development of Hong Kong studies? I doubt it.”

;

;Hong Kong arts funding body pulls 2 grants over national security law concerns

;

;Bookseller Sherry Lam, 25, was concerned that books published in Taiwan might be detained by customs. She was relieved when the latest batch of Hong Kong Diaries arrived.

;

;“These fears, shared by some other booksellers, are not unfounded. We have heard of such incidents but do not know where the red line lies,” said Lam, who has been running Jisaam Books in Mong Kok with two partners since October 2019.

;

;The public library catalogue provided the main indication of where the red lines lay.

;

;“If all works by certain writers are removed from shelves, we have a rough idea how sensitive this figure might be in the eyes of the government, and think through our next steps,” she said.

;

;As Hong Kong bookstores evolve, she has been trying to make her shop more like a library, a place where people can browse, stay as long as they like and feel at home.

;

;There is a guitar at the centre of the shop, and customers have to remove their shoes before entering.

;

;At the same time, she felt there was a difference between what shops and libraries did for Hongkongers.

;

;“Public libraries serve a key role of knowledge inheritance and making information freely accessible to everyone, something bookstores can never achieve,” she said.

;

;'Need to stop ideas from disappearing'

;

;As the action played out in public libraries and bookstores, Hong Kong schools were also drawn in.

;

;The Post learned that Sheng Kung Hui Lam Kau Mow Secondary School, a subsidised school in Sha Tin, was told by the authorities to remove books by Lu Xun, one of China's best known modern writers and a critic of the country's feudal and imperial practices in the early 20th century.

;

;Some schools removed 1984, another classic by George Orwell, to “avoid potential complaints”, according to Lui Chi-kong, a former school librarian who leads an advocacy group, Quality Library Network.

;

;He called for clearer guidelines by education authorities to erase teachers' doubts about what was permissible.

;

;But primary school principal Choy Sai-hung, chairman of advocacy group Education Convergence, was against having a list of challenged books for schools to adhere to.

;

;“Librarians and educators are book lovers who are professional enough to determine what's suitable on campuses. There is an effective mechanism to deal with this,” he said.

;

;Lawmaker Gary Zhang Xinyu was in favour of removing books that violated Hong Kong laws blatantly, but warned against an “overkill” by frontline public officers, especially when vetting works that required them to exercise subjective judgment.

;

;“It would be a huge obstacle to governance if some civil servants overkilled in the name of the national security law and political correctness,” he said.

;

;The wave of removals has prompted some book lovers to save copies for themselves or to send to universities in Taiwan and Britain.

;

;After the national security law was imposed and public libraries began removing books, teacher Song Chor-on rented a storage space to keep titles no longer available in libraries. His collection has grown to more than 650.

;

;5 Hong Kong speech therapists behind children's books jailed 19 months each

;

;A substitute Chinese teacher in primary and secondary schools, he has made an internet appeal for help to build an online archive to catalogue the pulled books and make them available for private circulation.

;

;“There is a saying that 'the shot hits the bird that pokes its head out'. I do worry for myself,” Song said.

;

;“As a teacher who loves books, I can't force my students to read, but hope to prevent a set of ideas from disappearing.”

;Xiaomi contracted home-grown Optiemus Electronics Ltd. to make its Bluetooth neckband earphones – the first time an Indian supplier will make an audio product for the Beijing-based tech giant, Muralikrishnan B, president of Xiaomi India, said in an interview.

;

;“This marks our entry into a whole new set of categories,” Muralikrishnan said late last week at an Optiemus factory in the Noida suburb of Indian capital New Delhi. “We see this as a milestone, as further proof of our commitment to making in India.”

;

;Xiaomi led India's smartphone market for years, but allegations of money laundering and increased state scrutiny contributed to a decline of more than 20 per cent in its shipments in the country last year, according to research firm Counterpoint. It ranked third in the last quarter of 2022, also hurt by tough competition, component shortages and an excessively wide product portfolio that confused customers and retailers.

;

;South Korean rival Samsung Electronics Co. beat Xiaomi to the top spot in the period, and has since reinforced its manufacturing push in India by locally building its fold and flip smartphones as well as its latest Galaxy S23 flagship.

;

;Xiaomi is now betting on the growing demand for smart TVs, Bluetooth earphones and other accessories to boost revenue in the country.

;

;Apple opens first retail store in India as country turns into new production hub

;

;Previously, Xiaomi and some of its Chinese rivals were hesitant to make earphones and smartwatches in India as it was easier to import these products from China to a market where demand was still budding. But as Indian state agencies' crackdown on Chinese firms intensified, they've rushed to explore manufacturing alliances with local companies, possibly to win Delhi's favour.

;

;Helping local companies such as Optiemus, Lava International Ltd. and Dixon Technologies India Ltd. to become global players is a key goal in Prime Minister Narendra Modi's drive to make India an export hub.

;

;“The Xiaomi partnership reflects the steady rise of home-grown companies, which are capable of feeding not just India's demand but can also export to the global market,” said Nitesh Gupta, a director at Optiemus, which also counts Apple Inc.'s Taiwanese supplier Wistron Corp. as a strategic partner.

;

;Indian smartphone maker Lava is in advanced talks with China's Huaqin Technology Co. to create an electronics manufacturing venture that would aim to win contracts from US and Chinese customers, it was reported in October.

;;

;Three years ago, when Juliana Lam, a clothes-making entrepreneur, returned to Hong Kong after a business trip and saw news reports about elderly people struggling to obtain face masks and having to wear the same disposable mask for several days during the pandemic, she determined to make a difference.

;

;“I had two boxes of disposable facial masks with 50 pieces each at the time, but I knew that giving them all away wouldn't solve the problem,” said Lam, the chairman of Julius Industries, a Hong Kong-based manufacturer of gloves and fashion accessories that counts Gap and Walmart among its clients.

;

;Lam decided to develop a reusable face mask that would be effective against the coronavirus and have a minimal impact on the environment.

;

;She brought in a team of research and development experts from the UK, poured millions of dollars into research, and established a new retail brand, Innotier, the following year.

;

;Innotier's products, which include masks, clothes and bed sheets, can inhibit and eliminate 99 per cent of the Covid-19 virus immediately upon contact, and the mask can last for up to 200 washes, she said.

;

;Lam claims that customers do not need to wash the mask every day and that it can be worn for almost four years.

;

;Now, as the Covid-19 virus resurges with borders between Hong Kong and the rest of the world fully open, Lam believes it is a good time to raise fresh capital to expand into overseas markets such as mainland China and Saudi Arabia.

;

;She opened her first pop-up store in Shanghai this month and has been exploring opportunities to cooperate with Saudi Arabia's health authorities to bring her products to the Middle East.

;

;Last week, executives from the Future Investment Initiative Institute, also known as the FII Institute, came to visit her shop in Sheung Wan to gain a better understanding of her products. FII is a non-profit organisation run by the Public Investment Fund, Saudi Arabia's main sovereign wealth fund.

;

;The technology behind Lam's product involves the release of silver ions from the fibres. The positively charged ions are released in the presence of respiratory moisture and act to eliminate viruses and bacteria on the surface of the fabrics, according to Lam.

;

;Silver has been used for centuries in medicine to prevent infection, reduce inflammation and kill bacteria.

;

;The strong antiviral properties of silver nanoparticles could be used to tackle current and future variants of the coronavirus, according to an article posted by The National Library of Medicine (NLM).

;

;Although many silver ion products claim to block the coronavirus, Lam's have been approved by international institutions such as SGS, one of the world's leading inspection, verification and certification organisations.

;

;Lam's background is in the AML Group, a gloves maker co-founded in 1963 by her father, Frank Lam-Chi-kuen, and Edward Cheng Wing-chung.

;

;By the early 2010s, AML had sales of over HK$1 billion and counted major brands such as J. Crew, Gap and Nike as clients. It was churning out 40 million pairs of gloves from 20 production bases in China, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Indonesia and Cambodia.

;

;Lam joined her father's company after graduating from the University of Toronto in 1996 and was the managing director before it shut down when Cheng and the Lam family parted ways. She dabbled in a few business ventures before setting up her own manufacturing business, Julius Group, in 2016.

;

;The establishment of Innotier has earned Lam several awards, including Sustainability Leader of the Year and the Hong Kong Sustainability Award from the Hong Kong Management Association.

;

;“It is worth noting that masks take up to 450 years to degrade in the sea, and Innotier's commitment to protecting the environment while doing business is commendable,” she said.
